Open Government Data

Source: vignettes/od_table.Rmd
od_table.Rmd

od_table() makes it easy to import datasets from the open data portal into your R sessions. This function does use direct downloads from the fileserver and therefore no API key is required.

In this example, we will use a data set about cancer statistics. The dataset id OGD_krebs_ext_KREBS_1 can be extracted from the url and will be used in the data import.

Import

To import a dataset, provide the dataset id as an argument.

table <- od_table("OGD_krebs_ext_KREBS_1")

The returned object is of class od_table and provides an overview of the dataset via the print() method.

table
## An object of class od_table
## 
## Database:   Cancer statistics by reporting year, province of residence and localisation of cancer 
## Measures:   Number of records F-KRE 
## Fields:     Tumore ICD/10 3-Steller, Reporting year, Province of residence, Sex 
## 
## Request:    2021-07-20 11:58:24 
## STATcubeR:  0.2.0.9000

Metadata

Information from OGD_krebs_ext_KREBS_1_HEADER.csv can be obtained via $meta$measures and $meta$fields. Similar to sc_table, the columns nitems and type give additional information that are produced by the parser.

table$meta$fields
  code               label                   label_en              nitems type        total_code
  <chr>              <chr>                   <chr>                  <int> <chr>       <chr>     
1 C-TUM_ICD10_3ST-0  Tumore ICD/10 3-Steller NA                        94 Category    NA        
2 C-BERJ-0           Berichtsjahr            Reporting year            36 Time (year) NA        
3 C-BUNDESLAND-0     Bundesland              Province of residence      9 Category    NA        
4 C-KRE_GESCHLECHT-0 Geschlecht              Sex                        2 Category    NA

The method table$field() can be used to get information about specific fields. For example, the information from OGD_krebs_ext_KREBS_1_C-KRE_GESCHLECHT-0.csv is available through this call.

table$field("Sex")
  code         label    label_en parsed
  <chr>        <chr>    <chr>    <chr> 
1 GESCHLECHT-1 mÃ¤nnlich male     male  
2 GESCHLECHT-2 weiblich female   female

Unlike the metadata in sc_table, the od_table class always contains german and english labels. Both can be used to label the dataset.

Table Contents

To get the actual microdata from OGD_krebs_ext_KREBS_1.csv, use table$data_raw. The output is similar to what is returned from read.csv2("OGD_krebs_ext_KREBS_1.csv").

table$data_raw
   `C-TUM_ICD10_3ST-0` `C-BERJ-0` `C-BUNDESLAND-0` `C-KRE_GESCHLECHT-0` `F-KRE`
   <fct>               <fct>      <fct>            <fct>                  <int>
 1 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-1     GESCHLECHT-1               2
 2 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-2     GESCHLECHT-1               8
 3 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-2     GESCHLECHT-2               2
 4 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-3     GESCHLECHT-1               6
 5 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-3     GESCHLECHT-2               2
 6 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-4     GESCHLECHT-1              12
 7 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-4     GESCHLECHT-2               2
 8 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-5     GESCHLECHT-1               4
 9 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-6     GESCHLECHT-1               5
10 TUM_ICD10_3ST-C00   BERJ-1983  BUNDESLAND-6     GESCHLECHT-2               2
# â€¦ with 45,049 more rows

od_table() makes sure that the levels of all factor columns are in the same order as in the metadata.

levels(table$data_raw$`C-BUNDESLAND-0`) == table$field("C-BUNDESLAND-0")$code
## [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE

If you want to use labels rather than codes, a labelled version of the data can be obtained via table$data. The labelling is done by mapping codes to english names using the previsously mentioned metadata.

table$data
   `Tumore ICD/10 3-Steller`            `Reporting year` `Province of residence` Sex    `Number of records F-KRE`
   <fct>                                <date>           <fct>                   <fct>                      <int>
 1 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Burgenland "           male                           2
 2 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Carinthia"             male                           8
 3 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Carinthia"             female                         2
 4 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Lower Austria"         male                           6
 5 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Lower Austria"         female                         2
 6 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Upper Austria"         male                          12
 7 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Upper Austria"         female                         2
 8 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Salzburg"              male                           4
 9 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Styria"                male                           5
10 <C00> BÃ¶sartige Neubildung der Lippe 1983-01-01       "Styria"                female                         2
# â€¦ with 45,049 more rows

Time variables are parsed automatically into a Date format if they satisfy certain STATcube standards.

A Trip to Germany

It is possible to switch the language used for labelling the dataset using the $language field. This field can be used to get and set the language. Allowed options are "en" for english and "de" for german.

table$language
## [1] "en"
table$language <- "de"

This option affects the print method as well as the output of $data by using the appropritate columns in table$meta and table$field(i). If no english labels are available, the german labels are used as a fallback mechanism.

table
## An object of class od_table
## 
## Database:   Krebsstatistik 
## Measures:   Anzahl der DatensÃ¤tze F-KRE 
## Fields:     Tumore ICD/10 3-Steller, Berichtsjahr, Bundesland, Geschlecht 
## 
## Request:    2021-07-20 11:58:24 
## STATcubeR:  0.2.0.9000
table$data

Further reading

Open data datasets often contain a large amount of rows. Check out the Tabulation article to see how they can be summarized into a more compact form.

STATcubeR caches all files requested from the server under the hood. To see where those caches are stored, see the caching article.
